Award.AwardTitle: Homological Behavior of Modules over Commutative Local Rings
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to contribute towards understanding the homological behavior of modules over commutative rings. Modules are the objects on which a given ring acts: geometrically, they correspond to bundles and, more generally, sheaves on a space. Sega will study certain classes of commutative local rings which extend in several directions the well-studied class of complete intersection rings, and will investigate to what extent the known properties of complete intersections can be translated to a larger context. Earlier work of the PI, in collaboration with D. Jorgensen, has shown that vanishing of cohomology over non-complete intersection rings can have rather non-rigid behavior. The accent in the proposed work is shifted towards finding a common bridge between complete intersections and other good classes of rings. Attention will be paid to vanishing of (co)homology, properties of the minimal free resolutions of modules, Betti numbers and other homologically defined invariants. An important aspect is an effort to show that the classes of rings and the modules considered occur abundantly in a variety of situations of geometric interest.

Commutative algebra allows one to encode information regarding solution sets of polynomial equations into objects such as rings and modules, and further understand their structure, using algebraic tools and a recent infusion of techniques from other fields that deal with physical spaces, such as topology. This method of encoding information and its further study is relevant to almost any area of mathematics, and to theoretical physics. In particular, the classes of rings and the properties considered in this project are relevant in the field of algebraic geometry, and some of the methods and outcomes make connections with the field of non-commutative algebra.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solution spaces of systems of linear equations over a field are described and studied by means of algebraic structures called vector spaces, with well-established applications in engineering, physics, natural sciences, computer science and social sciences.  A generalization of the notions of field and vector space led to the theory of rings and modules. Commutative rings can be used to encode information provided by multivariable polynomials, and provide a structural setting for analyzing geometric properties of surfaces defined by such polynomials. Modules that have a basis are called free, but in general minimal generators of a module may not be linearly independent. Thus one can consider relations among generators, and then relations among relations and so on. This process of identifying relations can be infinite, and the information is encoded into so-called free resolutions. When the ring is local or graded, we can talk about minimal free resolutions, and the minimal number of relations required at each step in the process are called Betti numbers of the module.  This project is concerned with understanding the infinite sequences of Betti numbers.  Basic questions such as whether such numbers satisfy recurrence relations are addressed.

Intellectual merit: One of the major achievements of the PI’s work concerns a class of local rings called Gorenstein Artinian algebras. Such rings are said to be generic if the coefficients involved in defining them (via a correspondence called the Macaulay inverse system) are chosen generically, i.e. in a dense open subset of an affine space. The PI and her collaborator(s) proved that all Betti sequences over such rings eventually satisfy a specific recurrence relation. Examples of Betti sequences with non-recursive behavior are known. Consequently, good (recursive) behavior occurs when the rings are chosen generically enough, despite the fact that recursive behavior does not always occur. This idea has been further exploited by the PI and her student, by exploring other remarkable structural properties of the free resolutions over generic Gorenstein Artinian algebras.

One of the most successful methods of understanding Betti numbers and related properties consists of  passing from a given ring to one that is simpler, via a non-zero divisor, if available, and analyzing how these properties change under the change of ring. Another achievement of the project is an extension of this change of rings idea, dealing with situations when non-zero divisors may not exists. The change in the Betti numbers and other properties via a ``quasi-complete intersection homomorphism” are analyzed in work of the PI and her collaborators, and concrete formulas are given.  

Broader impacts:  The results of this research were made available through publication in peer reviewed journals, and talks at conferences. The PI gave talks at three international conferences, and has several collaborators. The PI was the advisor of two non-traditional PhD students. One of them graduated and currently holds a tenure-track assistant professor position. The PI co-organized conferences, and made sure that to invite, among others, younger researchers, and members of underrepresented groups. The PI is acting as Principal Graduate Advisor in her department, and has also been involved in the organization of a large outreach activity aimed at local Kansas City high schools, with the purpose of emphasizing the importance of studying mathematics, and guiding them towards a possible career in mathematics or other science fields.
